title: I (once) Waited until Marriage to Have Sex — and That Was a Mistake

content: I (once) Waited until Marriage to Have Sex — and That Was a Mistake July 2000, Pasadena, California “I think we should wait.”   I announce this, breathless, as I walk in the door of my fiancée’s Craftsman bungalow. Elizabeth is baking zucchini bread, oven mitts on her hands. She cocks her head to one side, not sure what I mean.  “I mean we should stop having sex until after we’re married. I’ve rethought everything…. I’m ready to wait to do it right.” Elizabeth and I met on Matchmaker.com in February, 2000. Elizabeth was quiet for a few minutes. “Okay,” she said, nestling into me. “We can make that work.” Two nights later, we have sex for the first time.  Elizabeth was not a virgin. Don’t ask for love like a great fire, for that will burn the house down.” Divorced twice before I was 30, I’d seen plenty of houses burned down. Maybe mom was right. Elizabeth and I could have a lovely little house together, warmed not by the flames of sexual passion, but the electric blanket of deep tenderness, shared goals, and long walks through Altadena with her pit bull. Elizabeth and I get engaged in June, with a wedding planned for the following May.
